fullText: This revival of Rodgers and Hammerstein's 1945 musical is handsome and well-performed, but it doesn't solve the show's fundamental problems with its problematic male protagonist.
dtliExcerpt: This revival of Rodgers and Hammerstein's 1945 musical is handsome and well-performed, but it doesn't solve the show's fundamental problems with its problematic male protagonist.
bwwExcerpt: Carousel's sumptuous new Broadway revival plows steadily through the show's darker currents. Director Jack O'Brien invites us to admire the show as an exemplar of classic American musical theater, lovingly emphasizing its virtues. Prime among them is Rodgers and Hammerstein's innovative and varied score, repolished by orchestrator Jonathan Tunick and sterlingly sung by the cast; Henry offers a powerful account of Billy's long and winding first-act finale, 'Soliloquy,' and opera star Ren√©e Fleming-though too grand in manner for the role of Julie's kindly cousin-adds elegant vocal luster to the stirring 'You'll Never Walk Alone.' The gorgeous choreography, by New York City Ballet's Justin Peck, is danced with aplomb by a very fine ensemble led by NYCB's Brittany Pollack and Amar Ramasar. Santo Loquasto's set, Ann Roth's costumes and Brian MacDevitt's lighting are first-class.
